awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of hydrogeophysical downhole nuclear magnetic resonance instrument to support research and student training
awd_abstract_narration:
1531313
Parsekian 

Funding from this Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant will enable an early career investigator to acquire a wireline, borehole nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) well logging tool to be used for investigations of subsurface hydrologic properties.  NMR spectroscopy is sensitive to Hydrogen nuclei and has long been used for hydrocarbon exploration.  The proposed NMR instrument is designed to fit into standard groundwater wells and is tuned to pick up the resonant frequencies specific to Hydrogen nuclei.  The borehole NMR instrument would become part of the Facility for Imaging of the Near & Subsurface Environment (FINSE), an established Instrument facility at UW managed by trained staff and would support the field analytical capabilities of the Wyoming Center for Environmental Hydrology and Geophysics (WyCEHG), a center of excellence in hydro geophysics funded by NSF/EPSCoR.  

The NMR well logging tool will offer greatly improved spatial ( < 0.5 m) and temporal resolution of subsurface hydrological parameters over conventional methods that typically aggregate subsurface hydrological observations over 10s of meters so the knowledge gained has the potential to be transformative and therefore supports NSF mission of promoting the progress of science..  The investigators intend to deploy the NMR tool for studies in vadose zone hydrology of interest to Critical Zone Observatories supported by NSF Division of Earth Sciences and studies of permafrost in the high Arctic; the instrument will be useful for groundwater resource assessment thus promoting the national welfare.  The instrument will support hands on experiential learning by students using the NMR tool for studies of regional interest thereby fostering their future employability in fields that routinely engage in subsurface hydrologic studies, another aspect of the proposal that is congruent with NSFs mission of promoting the national welfare.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the acquisition of a downhole nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) borehole geophysical tool. This instrument is used in wells for the evaluation of water in porous or fractured geologic materials. The downhole-NMR has become part of the University of Wyoming Near Surface Geophysical Instrumentation Center, an established instrument facility at the University. Through the course of this project, the NMR instrument supported research related to projects in the fields of fractured rock hydrogeology, agricultural hydrology, and understanding how rocks weather. Thanks to this NMR instrument, a new understanding of geophysical prediction of groundwater flow properties has been developed, return flow in irrigated agricultural field has been observed, and the subsurface interface of weathering rocks has been measured. Downhole-NMR is the only geophysical logging method that is directly and unambiguously sensitive to water and can be used to evaluate aquifer properties related to water flow. This instrument is enabling advancements in subsurface characterization that are needed to drive hydrologic models, thereby advancing knowledge of the mechanisms that control surface and subsurface hydrologic processes. Downhole-NMR capability has providing educational opportunities for students that are complementary to existing programs in geophysics and hydrology at the University of Wyoming. Students trained on the instrument ranged from high school to undergraduate and graduate level, as well as postdocs. In most cases, research products enabled by this instrument were led by students or students were heavily involved in the measurement. The research this project has enabled, and will continue to enable, has an impact on society by enhancing our understanding of hydrologic systems – critical information for ensuring water resources security.
